awd_titl_txt: Type II: Polsky Center I-Corps Program
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, from the Polsky Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation at the University of Chicago extends their existing I-Corps Site grant. 

NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. This is a Type II proposal, requesting a "renewal" of funding for an existing I-Corps Site. There are two types of I-Corps Site proposals. Type I proposals are submitted by institutions that have not had prior funding as an I-Corps Site. These proposals may request $100,000 per year for up to five years. Type II proposals are submitted by institutions that have had prior funding as an I-Corps Site. These proposals may request up to $100,000 per year for up to three years.

Through their initial Site grant, the University of Chicago served approximately 90 STEM teams, including innovative faculty, researchers, and students from the University of Chicago community and other Chicagoland institutions. Several of these teams were successful ? winning further grant funding, raising outside capital, hiring staff, and launching companies. Upon the renewal of their Site grant, the Polsky Center seeks to: 1) continue serving campus constituents, and 2) broadening access of these resources to underserved and underrepresented populations in the Chicagoland region whose universities do not currently provide access to Site resources. Through this goal, Polsky aims to increase economic development in Illinois and empower innovators to test their ideas.

The Polsky Center has been a recognized leader in the development and launch of ventures that create economic value, supporting an increasing number of companies launching from technical divisions, including: the Computation Institute, the Medical Center, and the Institute for Molecular Engineering. Additionally, the University of Chicago manages national laboratories, including the Department of Energy Labs Argonne and Fermi, as well as the Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole. The University of Chicago is committed to also supporting technology transfer from these institutions, which have received federal funding.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The University of Chicago I-Corps Site program is operated by the Polsky Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation. The Polsky Center drives venture creation and technology commercialization within the University of Chicago and the surrounding community. Through education, partnerships, and new venture support, the Polsky Center advances the knowledge and practice of entrepreneurship and accelerates the commercialization of research. The Polsky Center helps students, faculty, staff, alumni, researchers and local entrepreneurs navigate the complex process of creating and growing a startup.

During the course of its second I-Corps Site Grant, the Polsky Center I-Corps Program served 171 entrepreneurial teams. The Polsky Center ran three 7-week-long program cohorts each academic year and served faculty, researchers, and students in the STEM fields. Notably, over the course of the second grant, faculty participation in the program increased by over 52%, which demonstrates the marked demand for entrepreneurial programming at the University of Chicago, as well as the Polsky Center?s concerted efforts to engage this audience. The Polsky Center seamlessly transitioned the I-Corps site program to a virtual format beginning in March 2020. The ability to continuously offer the program, and develop virtual capabilities, reflects the Polsky Center?s focus on responding to participant needs and continuing to provide high-quality support.

The intellectual merit for the project included the development of a curriculum to teach STEM innovators early-stage entrepreneurship skills, including customer discovery and interview techniques. Participants practiced these skills by conducting a minimum of 30 customer discovery interviews while participating in the program. Participants learned how to derive insight using entrepreneurial frameworks such as the Business Model Canvas and the Value Proposition Canvas. During the COVID-19 pandemic, the Polsky Center utilized supplemental funding from the NSF to create videos that included the majority of the curriculum content. Creating these virtual resources added tremendous value for program participants as well as the development of the Polsky I-Corps site program overall.

The project had broad impact by supporting the development of a culture of innovation at the University of Chicago. The Polsky Center I-Corps Program became an entry point for faculty, researchers, and students to local and national entrepreneurial ecosystems, including: networks of support, additional entrepreneurial programs, and follow-on funding opportunities. As a result, graduates of the Polsky Center I-Corps Program have gone on to raise additional grant and venture funding in excess of $336 million as of summer 2022. Of this funding, over $28 million is in the form of SBIR/STTR grants from the NSF and other federal agencies. In addition, during the 2021-22 academic year alone, three startups that previously participated in Polsky I-Corps achieved successful exits.

In conclusion, the project spurred the creation of a critical entrepreneurial resource on the University of Chicago campus. The Polsky Center I-Corps program looks forward to continuing to support a culture of innovation through participation in the Great Lakes Region I-Corps Hub. This opportunity will allow future STEM innovators to explore the potential of their ideas and connects them to a network of resources to help turn those ideas into ventures.

 


Last Modified: 08/05/2022
Modified by: Steven N Kaplan
